reviewText: I am a big fan of Steve McQueen and I have watched several episodes of Wanted Dead or Alive.  I am excited about the series coming out on DVD.  It is hard to find this series on VHS and when found they are expensive.  Steve McQueen played Josh Randall with a calm Mid-Western type attitude with a sense of humor. McQueen does not play the tough guy looking for a fight, instead he was a gentlemen to the ladies and kept calm in most situations.  He was a bounty hunter doing his job and when pushed he used his rifle with speed and accuracy.  The series is dated because you can tell right away who is bad and who is good and it is in black and white. Although, I like the camera angles in most of the episodes they are very good.  Richard Donner directed a few episodes and there are several episodes that take place outdoors.  The best part is Steve McQueen was a great actor even while on T.V. and he was the "King of Cool" on Wanted Dead or Alive.
summary: Wanted Dead or Alive is cool

reviewText: In the late 1950's, the Western was a TV staple..Gunsmoke, Bat Masterson, Wyatt Earp, Have Gun With Travel, Maverick, Sugarfoot and of course The Lone Ranger.Wanted Dead or Alive was a rare bred of TV show.. .A hunter who was soft spoken and smart. He let his gun do the talking when most would challedge. However Josh Randall was intelligent, a thinking man..not a man who will be bullied around, so guns were used sparinglySteve McQueen, fresh from Studio one production of the Defenders and the movie the Blob,  took this role and brought the TV western into a new hero-the anti hero.  The Bounty Hunter was always the bad guy in the movies and early TV.McQueen brought a softer side to the harden professional. That is why Wanted Dead or Alive and Have Gun will Travel survive in western lore and DVD  box set, because of its intelligenceIt also showed why McQueen was a great action hero!...he learned from his time on wanted (also what he reported told Walker Texas Ranger's Chuck Norris) "Always let the ACTION do the talking" and it always did! He later showed in Magnificent Seven and The Great EscapeBennet Pomerantz, AUDIOWORLD

reviewText: I give 5 stars to the show, others have explained why it deserves it, and I give a -5 to the packaging. As earlier reviewers have noted the discs are set in plastic trays that are attached together with tape! Not some specially designed extra strength industrial tape designed for the purpose, but thin clear packing tape designed to be easily cut and with limited adhesion. Add this to the fact that -as another person pointed out- you practically have to snap the discs in half to get them out of their trays! I have many other dvd collections and I have never had any trouble releasing discs, but when I tried to pull a disc loose from one of these taped in trays the tray ripped loose from the packaging with the disc still in it! Cheap, cheap, cheap packaging. And since earlier reviewers have called attention to this and it still hasn't been rectified I can only surmise that New Line Home Entertainment is deaf to customer concerns. Foolish.

reviewText: Steve McQueen may have been young and inexperienced when he shot this first season, but his acting didn't look like it needed much work.This TV series was the beginning of McQueen making a name for himself and honing his craft. After this, he began acting in films and became a big star. As "Josh Randall" in this western series, which ran about three years, he showed us the same guy we saw star in those films: a guy who was smooth, natural-sounding and a great actor.McQueen also had the benefit of some good writing in this series.  The 39 episodes have a lot of variation and they feature some well-known guest actors.  The older you are, the more you'll recognize these faces.  Overall, it's very entertaining and well worth the money.
summary: McQueen A Star Right Out Of The Gate!

reviewText: "King of Cool" actor Steve McQueen's breakthrough role was his late 1950's portrayal of bounty hunter Josh Randall on TV's "Wanted: Dead or Alive".  The DVD set for Season One includes 36 episodes plus a nice collection of featurettes about the series and about McQueen, who would go on to star in movie hits such as "The Magnificent Seven" and "The Great Escape."McQueen consciously played Josh Randall against the TV western hero stereotype.  In the show, bounty hunters are disliked as ruthless mercenaries not much removed from the criminals they hunted down.  In addition, Randall is portrayed as an ex-Confederate soldier and laconic loner, capable of quick and lethal violence.  However, McQueen gives Randall significant depth of character, with his own quiet but strong sense of justice and compassion that is frequently at odds with his occupation.  McQueen gave Randall his own distinctive understated style, along with a unique sidearm, a sawed-off Winchester '94."Wanted: Dead or Alive" was a good TV show with formula-breaking plots packed into short 30 minute action shows, in which Josh Randall often took the side of wronged men, women and children.  Production values are pretty simple compared to today's shows, with minimal special effects, but this is still good entertainment and highly recommended to fans of Steve McQueen.

reviewText: One of the most memorable and famous characters of the '50's Western genre was Steve McQueen's "Josh Randall", who spoke softly (with the Southern drawl he cultivated in his early days roaming around the South, particularly Myrtle Beach, S.C.) and carried a Big Gun, the sawed-off Winchester lever-action rifle then known as the "Mare's Laig". I remember the excitement each week eagerly waiting for each episode of this great Western.One of my fondest childhood memories was the weekend I spent with my Dad, helping him to hand make my own custom-made leather belt rig from scratch for my toy "Mare's Laig" in time for use as part of a Halloween costume when the plastic original proved to be a poor replica.With all the second-rate wastage flooding the DVD market lately, it's really great to see New Line Ent. bring back such a great actor in a great Western!
summary: Josh Randall and his "Mare's Laig" Ride Again! ! !
Title: N/A

reviewText: CBS and New Line Home Entertainment present "WANTED DEAD OR ALIVE", featuring Steve McQueen as the gentleman bounty hunter Josh Randall...a man of few words who carried on his belt an 1892 Winchester lever action pistol, which he fondly called "Mare's Leg"...originally introduced in an episode of the TV Western "Trackdown"...this was the beginning of a beautiful role that lasted for three seasons for Mr. Steve McQueen that catapulted him to stardom.First time on DVD with all 36 Original Episodes of Season One...loaded with extras.Disc One (Side A)...with title and directors:THE MARTIN POSTER (Thomas Carr) (guest star: Michael Landon & Nick Adams)FATAL MEMORY (Thomas Carr)THE BOUNTY ( Thomas Carr)DEAD END (Thomas Carr)(Special Features...Genesis of Wanted:Dead or Alive...Steve McQueen Bio Part One...Color Episode of "The Martin Poster")Disc One (Side B)...with title and directors:PASSING OF SHAWNEE BILL (Thomas Carr)THE GIVEAWAY GUN (Donald McDougall)RANSOM FOR A NUN (Donald McDougall)MIRACLE AT THE POT HOLE (Thomas Carr)(Special Features..."The Bounty Hunter" featurette...Photo Gallery)Disc Two (Side A)...with title and directors:THE FOURTH HEADSTONE (Donald McDougall)TIL DEATH DO U PART (Donald McDougall)THE FAVOR (Thomas Carr)RICHOCHET (Donald McDougall)(Special Features..."Life in the Fast Lane" Documentary Parts 1 & 2)Disc Two (Side B)...with title and directors:SHERIFF OF RED ROCK (Thomas Carr)DIE BY THE GUN (Donald McDougall)RAWHIDE BREED (Donald Mcdougall)EIGHT CENT REWARD (Thomas Carr)(Special Features...Steve McQueen Filmography...Steve McQueen Bio Part 2...Color Episode of "The Favor")Disc Three (Side A)...with title and directors:DROP TO DRINK (Donald McDougall)ROPE LAW (Thomas Carr)SIX-UP TO BANNACH (Thomas Carr)THE SPUR (Donald Mcdougall)(Special Features..."Angel or Devil" featurette...Photo Gallery)Disc Three (Side B)...with title and directors:REUNION FOR REVENGE (R.G. Springsteen) (guest star: James Coburn)COMPETITION (R.G. Springsteen)CALL YOUR SHOT (Donald McDougall)SECRET BALLOT (Donald McDougall)(Special Features..."Life in the Fast Lane" Documentary Parts 3 & 4)Disc Four (Side A)...with title and directors:THE CORNER (R.G. Springsteen)THE EAGER MAN (Donald McDougall)THE LEGEND (Thomas Carr) (guest star: Michael Landon)RAILROADED (Thomas Carr)DOUBLE FEE (Donald McDougall)THE KOVACK AFFAIR (Thomas Carr) (guest star: James Coburn)(Special Features...Steve McQueen Bio Part 3...Color Episode of "Six-Up to Bannach")Disc Four (Side B)...with title and directors:BOUNTY FOR A BRIDE (Donald McDougall)CROSSROADS (Donald McDougall)ANGELS OF VENGEANCE (R.G. Springsteen)THE LITTLE CLIENT (Thomas Carr)THE CONQUERORS (Thomas Carr)AMOS CARTER (Thomas Carr)(Special Features..."Dead End" featurette..."Life in the Fast Lane" Documentary Parts 5 & 6...Photo Gallery)Hats off (Cowboy Hats, that is) to Studio Canal, New Line Home Entertainment and CBS for taking us back to those thrilling '50s TV Westerns...tagged with the name "King of Cool" this legendary actor and TV series will never be forgotten...the clarity and format is top notch featuring great character actors of B-Westerns in every episode with McQueen...watching these episodes brings back so many wonderful memories of the times when television cared about cast and storyline...gotta love it!Total Time: 4-DVD-Set ~ New Line Home Entertainment N8161 ~ (6/07/2005)
summary: "36 Original Episodes of the King of Cool ~ Steve McQueen"

reviewText: Steve McQueen starring in his most memorable role.  Many "bounty hunters" were of about the same character as those they hunted.  Josh Randall was the exception.  In fact, he gave most of his reward money to either the victim of the person he hunted or the hunted's family.  Randall was a complex man, but a really good person.  He made sure that he was in the right and then he went ahead.  A western of "true grit".

reviewText: My wife and I have just finished watching (and reading) everything on these discs. We thought that the episodes looked great, and that the extras were just fine. Really, these studios are not obligated to include any extras, and this is just brimming with them. But, wouldn't you think that such a large amount of effort is a waste when the packaging falls apart to reveal how it was bound together to begin with? (Each disc is housed on their own plastic "pages," or panels, which are bound at the spine; just like a book.) It's not enough that it fell apart, but it's bound with what appears to be packaging tape! Can you believe that? HOW OBTUSE!!! You know that these discs are more than likely going be allowed to slip quietly out of print, which means that long after the incredibly cheap packaging has failed (and judging from the copy I own, it'll probably be sometime next week), we're going to be scrambling for ways to protect double-sided discs; which are difficult enough to care for when kept in their proper cases. I don't believe that we're owed any extras, but I DO believe that there should be enough pride on the studio's part, as well as a sense of obligation to the consumer to at least make a container which will properly house and protect the product being offered!The show? Great!The DVD quality? Great!The packaging? DISGRACEFUL!!!

reviewText: You should like this if you like Steve McQueen and are interestred in his early career. It's kind of funny now to watch the state of 50's TV, but Steve McQueen, as Bounty Hunter with a heart Josh Randall, is great to watch, being his usual, seemingly detached self. He was tough when he needed to be, but was not above leaving the bounty behind for the benefit of a needy young widow. The series was, of course, in black and white, and events like fist fights reflect the status of 1950's filmmaking.A great series, very clear and crisp and great viewing.

reviewText: Every episode shows how Steve McQueen earned the title "King of Cool."  His Josh Randall sets the standard for the cowboy anti-hero!  Nearly 50 years after its TV debut, WANTED: DEAD OR ALIVE is still great, engrossing entertainment that totally buries the stuff on TV now-a-days!  The neat, clear transfer is crisp and the sound is fantastic!  The program never looked or sounded this good on our little, old, black-and-white, rabbit-eared Admiral TV set!I don't understand why the studio released this golden oldie in a folded cardboard sleeve containing plastic trays that are scotch-taped together!  You would think Newline would try to make the package something nice, with its artwork protected in a plastic case -- something along the lines of the way CBS packaged HAVE GUN WILL TRAVEL (each disc in a 1/2 width "keep case").  This is why I took off a star off my rating.  Neatness counts, and this packaging is the height of uncool -- almost as bad as those snap-cases!A few episodes in this set are colorized -- and inaccurately so, as admitted by the studio on disc.  Don't worry though, these episodes also appear in their original black-and-white format as well.  As with old movies, these TV shows were designed to be black-and-white.  The lighting folks, directors, and producers worked together to ensure the proper moods were conveyed in this medium.  It works in WANTED: DEAD OR ALIVE, so if it ain't broke, don't try to fix it!Finally, I would like to suggest that the studio forget about including colorized episodes.  Since the colors weren't done correctly in the first place, the episodes really can't provide anything of "historical value or interest."  The studio's production money can be put to much better use -- like improving their packaging!  Thank goodness for scanners, inkjet printers and commercially-available "keep cases"!
summary: TV Show Withstands Test of Time -- The Packaging Won't!

reviewText: I am almost through with season one. I got it for five dollars at Walmart. I am watching it on a widescreen/flat Sony 46" screen. I have to turn the tv up very loud to hear the audio. The video is ok to good most of the time, but sometimes it is not so good at all. I have been trying to adjust to the new tv now for some time. Everything or everyone looks fatter than they probably are. Anyway, the show is pretty simple. Steve McQueen is a kind hearted bounty hunter who cares as much about true justice as he does his bounty money. Much of the time too he seems to be working for free, preferring to do the right thing, and he tells folks to pay him when they can, stuff like that. The show isn't too bad at all but I think it would probably look more NORMAL on a regular tube style tv. I'm clearly not sold on the whole widescreen format. It just doesn't seem to work well on anything type of video that hss any age to it. But for the money Steve is good fun as bounty hunter Josh Randall.

reviewText: Steve McQueen, `The King of Cool', one of the biggest stars of the sixes and early seventies, got a big break on Wanted Dead Or Alive, a half hour western that ran on CBS for three seasons (1958-1961).  McQueen played Josh Randall, a bounty hunter, whose trademark weapon is a cut down Winchester rifle (Mare's leg) that he carries on his thigh.  Westerns dominated television at the time, but Wanted Dead Or Alive stands out from the pack, in part because of the high quality of the writing, as well as its charismatic star.  In this first season, which has a staggering thirty six episodes, Josh Randall is involved in a wide variety of adventures, and yet the writers don't really repeat themselves, and produce very few misfires.  Perhaps the number of men around with a price on their head is a little excessive, but for the most part, the situations that occur don't seem too outrageous or hard to believe, particularly when compared to other westerns of the era.  Although his job is deadly serious, Randall is a down to earth regular guy, not an amoral killer, just interested in the reward.McQueen first played bounty hunter Josh Randall on `Trackdown', another TV western, starring Robert Culp.  Apparently the Randall character was so popular, that the powers that be decided to create a series based on the bounty hunter.  While the writers do a fine job, it is Steve McQueen who has what it takes and more, to bring humanity and likeability to a character engaged in what some may regard as a despicable profession.  Randall's resourcefulness, skill, sexiness, and charm, help make him appealing to both males and females.As with most half hour dramas, things usually move fast.  Randall is sometimes on a quest to capture an outlaw.  Other times, because of his occupation and reputation, adventure comes his way, when someone has a job offer, or needs help of some kind.  Although he makes his living as a bounty hunter, money is not the most important thing to Randall, and he does more than his share of pro bono work.  For Josh, there isn't much time for romance.  Besides, more than a few of the women he does encounter, turn out to be quite hazardous to his health.The thirty six episodes are on four double sided discs.  Image quality is outstanding for a program of this age, however quality control could be a problem, and you may experience issues with the discs locking up during play.  There are some interesting extras including a bio, photo gallery, a number of featurettes about the series, including a six part documentary about the life of Steve McQueen, that is spread across several discs.  There are also colorized versions of selected episodes.  Season One of Wanted Dead or Alive, is very solid entertainment, and highly recommended to fans of Steve McQueen, and classic westerns.  The complete series is again available on DVD for close to the same price, so if you want to get josh Randall in his entirety, that is an economical option.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Steve McQueen was probably cool before we met him in this series but this is where we really began to know and appreciate his performance and persona. And he went from here to superstardom and he didn't have to evolve very far as a preformer to get there. The bounty hunter didn't enjoy a particularly positive reputation in the old west and McQueen's character played against that general perception bringing a code of fairness to the situation. The performances here are first rate as befitting a prime time series that this was when it originally aired. Production values are OK, not great (and reason for holding back on the fifth star above), but generally adequate. But scripts were intelligent and McQueen and most of the supporting casts performances were spot on (Michael Landon known for Bonanza and Little House is featured in a couple of these episodes). There's enough action to hold interest but these were not particularly action filled stories. Storytelling really takes presidence and that's fine.So for McQueen fans and western collectors this collection is a must have.  Now where the heck is season 2?
Title: N/A

reviewText: As a big fan of westerns, it is always a pleasure to see a season set such as this one hit the market. Only "Have Gun Will Travel" existed on a quality release before this set appeared. All the other western season sets ("Branded" and "The Guns of Will Sonnett") were put out as cheapy releases, and not worth the investment.I'm not sure I understand the complaint about the packaging. I have the "Freaks and Geeks" season set that uses exactly the same type of packaging, and haven't had any problems with it wearing out.The picture on the black and white episodes is superb. And I have no complaint of the inclusion of the color episodes from the early days of colorization either. After all, these episodes also appear on the release in B&W.; Even New Line made derogatory statements about these "color" episodes, and made it clear they were only included for historical purposes.Actually, my only complaint is a small one. At the close of the opening credits for each episodes, the name of the episode has been superimposed briefly, before the storyline continues. I don't know at what point this was added, but I'd prefer it hadn't been. (Note that in the color episodes, this is not the case.)
Title: N/A
